content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A solid wheel with an axle through its center is placed on a horizontal surface. Two identical springs are fixed to the axle on either side of the wheel. The other ends of the springs are fixed to a vertical wall, as shown in the Top View. The center of the wheel is then displaced a horizontal distance <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from equilibrium, as shown in the Side View. When released from rest, the wheel rolls without slipping and exhibits simple harmonic motion. A sensor at the center of the wheel measures only the maximum horizontal acceleration <math alttext="a sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>a</mi><mtext>max</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of the wheel as the wheel oscillates. A group of students is asked to experimentally determine the angular frequency <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> of the wheel’s oscillations about equilibrium using a linear graph. To determine <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math>, the students are only permitted to use measurements from a meterstick and the values of <math alttext="a sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> measured by the sensor. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine an experimental value of <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> using a linear graph. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

A solid wheel with an axle through its center is placed on a horizontal surface. Two identical springs are fixed to the axle on either side of the wheel. The other ends of the springs are fixed to a vertical wall, as shown in the Top View. The center of the wheel is then displaced a horizontal distance <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from equilibrium, as shown in the Side View. When released from rest, the wheel rolls without slipping and exhibits simple harmonic motion. A sensor at the center of the wheel measures only the maximum horizontal acceleration <math alttext="a sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>a</mi><mtext>max</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of the wheel as the wheel oscillates. A group of students is asked to experimentally determine the angular frequency <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> of the wheel’s oscillations about equilibrium using a linear graph. To determine <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math>, the students are only permitted to use measurements from a meterstick and the values of <math alttext="a sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> measured by the sensor. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine an experimental value of <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> using a linear graph. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be used to produce a linear graph, and how that graph could be analyzed to determine an experimental value of <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math>.

In a second experiment, using the same materials, students are asked to use a linear graph to experimentally determine the spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> of a single spring. The students measure the mass of the wheel to be <math alttext="M equals, 1.5 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>.The angular frequency of the oscillations can be shown to be <math alttext="omega equals, the square root of the fraction with numerator 2 k sub effective, end sub, and denominator 3 M, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>ω</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eff</mtext></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow></mfrac></msqrt></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="k sub effective" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>eff</mi></msub></math> is the effective spring constant of the springs.The students fix additional identical pairs of springs to either side of the axle of the wheel and the wall, set the wheel into simple harmonic motion, and measure the resulting angular frequency. ii. On the following grid, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) that can be used to determine <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw a best-fit line that best represents the data.

(d) Using the best-fit line that you drew in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> in part (c)(iii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.
